summary: Neuroblastoma is a type of cancer that forms in nerve cells called neuroblasts. It usually begins in the adrenal glands but can also start in the neck, chest, or spinal cord. Neuroblasts are immature nerve tissue that normally develop into working nerve cells, but in neuroblastoma, they form a tumor. It is the most common cancer in babies and the third-most common cancer in children.
causes: Changes in genes (gene variants or mutations)
Duplicated segments of the LMO1 gene
Copy-number variation within the NBPF10 gene
risk_factors: Parental factors around conception and during gestation (occupation, smoking, alcohol consumption, medicinal drug use, birth factors)
Exposure to infection early in life
Use of hormones and fertility drugs
symptoms: Lump in the abdomen, neck, or chest
Painless, bluish lumps under the skin
Inability to stand, crawl, or walk
Distinct bruising and swelling around the eyes
diagnosis: Imaging tests (x-rays, CT scan, ultrasound, MRI, MIBG scan)
Microscopy (small, round, blue cells, Homer Wright pseudorosettes)
International Neuroblastoma Risk Group Staging System (INRGSS)
treatments: High-dose chemotherapy and radiation therapy with stem cell rescue
